Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Adhere to professional standards and operational protocols.
Situation2: A mandatory pre-shift briefing on new operational procedures is about to start.
Story: I glance at my phone, the family group chat lighting up with photos of the holiday table, my mother’s message reminding me not to be late for the annual toast. My heart aches a little; this tradition means everything to my parents, and I know how much they count on me to be there, to uphold what our family has always done. But as I stand in the break room, the supervisor’s voice cuts through my thoughts, calling all operators to the mandatory pre-shift briefing. There’s a new set of operational protocols, and attendance is non-negotiable. Missing it could mean disciplinary action, or worse, risking passenger safety. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing down on me—my family’s expectations pulling me home, the responsibility of my job demanding my focus. My hands tremble as I try to decide which role I can afford to let down, knowing that either choice will leave someone disappointed, maybe even myself.
